title: 1: Intro to the terminal, git and codespaces.
text:
The terminal is a window on a machine that allows for the input and output of text. The shell is the primary interface that is run within the terminal, creating a command line interface (CLI). Choice of shell will effect user experience but not functionality, common shells include: bash, zhs, and fish.



ls - short for list (-a)
pwd - ‘print working directory’
cd - change directory
rm - short for remove
mkdir - short for make directory
touch -
cat
echo -
less
mv + use for renaming
cp
man
tree
chmod
clear

title: 1: Linux Command line skills
text:
The prompt
As a user the first time you open a terminal you will likely be greeted by a prompt. On codespaces this prompt will often take the form @{user} -> workspace/{repository} $ whereas on a standard linux machine the prompt often takes the form {user}@{hostname} $. Because of these differences most sources of information will simply show the prompt as the single $ that normally ends a prompt when they describe commands, it is important to remember that this symbol is not part of the command.


Your first command
Select your terminal and type the command pwd after the prompt. (pwd is an acronym for print working directory)
$ pwd
This command will print the full path of the current working directory, that is the location in the file system that the commands being run in the shell are being executed.
Now try this command. (ls is a shortening of the word list)
$ ls
This will output a list of the contents of the current directory. In most terminals this will be highlighted to suggest the kind of file system entry that each item is but otherwise we can use a slightly changed command to view this information.
$ ls -F
This command will append a trailing character to different types of directory entry: / for nested directories, * for executables, and @ for links. The -F part of this command is known as an option.


Options
Options are used to modify the behavior of a command being run and can do many different things. Rerunning the ls command again with the option -a will additionally reveal all the ‘hidden’ items in the directory (all the items with names starting with a .) and using the -l command will output a table with lots of additional information about the directory entries including size and last edit time.
